text: U.S. guy answers, shout out to Ben for this question. He says, why won't my order execute in regards to the whole trying to close the entire trade at once instead of closing one side at a time? It's a great question. And if it's everything to do with liquidity. So here's what happens. If you have multiple legs to your strategy, that's on. Like one, like two, maybe like three and four. What ends up happening? Is if I want to close this trade quickly, I can try to submit in order for all of these. Now, what that requires is a counter party that is looking for all of these at whatever price we pick, maybe 50 cents. So this takes longer. Think of anything that you try to sell. The more complicated it is, typically the more difficult it is to transact. Now, comparatively, if we exit one leg at a time, instead of trying to find somebody that wants all of these things, you're finding somebody that wants just this one thing. And then maybe finding somebody entirely different that wants just this one thing. And then so on and so forth. Now when we talk about the context of one, most of the time for the other side of this trade is going to be a market maker. But these individual trades go into a larger book of things.
